On a rock by the river reclin'd,</br>A youth was thus heard to complain,</br>While his harp warbled sweet to the wind,</br>And gave echo the sorrowful strain.
"All lost and abandon'd to care,</br>Distracted, ah!  where shall I fly</br>To evade the rude hand of Despair,</br>To be hid from stern Misery's eye.
"In vain do I court the still scene—</br>There fancy pourtrays the dear maid,</br>And amidst the sweet landscape serene,</br>Despair lurks in every shade.
"Unheard and unheeded along,</br>Meanders the musical stream,</br>Unheeded the lark tunes his song,</br>And soars as he warbles his theme.
"Ye winds as ye winnow the air,</br>As ye sing thro' the high-waving grove,</br>Ah!  could ye but whisper my fair</br>How well, how sincerely I love.
"But cease, my fond bosom, ah!  cease,</br>Life's winter will soon pass away,</br>And again the sweet sunshine of peace,</br>Shall glow with a ne'er-fading ray.
"And when o'er my moss-cover'd urn,</br>My harp in dumb sorrow shall lay;</br>Some friend o'er my ashes shall mourn,</br>And tenderly sighing shall say:
"'Ye poplars that wave on the hill,</br>Your branches all solemn along;</br>Ye firs of the woodland be still,</br>For your wandering Edwin is gone!
"'For no more he will muse in the grove,</br>All lost and abandon'd to care:</br>No more he will think on his love,</br>And sigh in the chains of despair.
"'Ye rocks that o'erlook the still shore,</br>Where oft he reclin'd his sick head;</br>Ye echo his music no more,</br>For Edwin, your Edwin, is dead!'"</br>
